text:
is there a reason why 
```make membersrvc```
reverts with
```make: Nothing to be done for `membersrvc'.```
<@U2CC1NDT2> the makefile tries to be smart about knowing if it needs to rebuild something
in this case, it thinks membersrvc is up to date
do you have a reason to believe it needs to be rebuilt?
its always possible there is a bug
for instance, if you edited any of the .go files, it should trigger a rebuild
if you find that you have edited files and it stays says “Nothing to be done”, there is a big
bug
how can he have edited files? he's not developing the fabric, he's playing with it, IIUC
I didn’t say he did….im saying that its normal for “make membersrvc” to say “Nothing to be done” if it believes there is nothing to be done
his question implied it was unexpected for it to do this
my guess is that the binary isn't found (by him) and his make isn't working
and indeed, if he edited files, it would be unexpected for it to do this
seems unlikely, but I am always open minded
<@U2CC1NDT2> you can check in ./build/bin
im guessing you will find you already have ./build/bin/membersrvc
also note, if you are working in the devenv, the ./build/bin directory should already be in your $PATH
so you can do things like “which membersrvc” or simply “membersrvc"
<@U2CC1NDT2> also apologies for dropping the ball on the request to update your fabric, was just reminded of this when reviewing the history
this is def a downside to having so many slack channels…easy to get distracted and then forget, heh
are you all set now or do you still need to get to the latest stuff?
<@U0KPFAZNF> - no worries - ended up killing everything and pulling the repo from scratch
I'm working through the docs ito a fresh install...

deploy vagrant steps - all ok
make peer - all ok
make unit-test - all ok
make node-sdk-unit-tests - failed
sudo make node-sdk-unit-tests -> results in...

```[RUN] unit tests...
ERROR: /src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/build/bin/membersrvc does not exist
make[1]: *** [unit-tests] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory `/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/sdk/node'
make: *** [node-sdk-unit-tests] Error 2```
that path looks suspect
"/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/build/bin/membersrvc does not exist"
make membersrvc - make: Nothing to be done for `membersrvc'.
it should have /opt/gopath prepended
right, i think the problem is the path
i suspect if you look in /opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/build/bin
you will see membersrvc is there
that is why the “make” says “nothing to do"
yup - it's there
the problem seems to be in the sdk unit-test environment
its looking in the wrong path
snap - how come that's failing
not sure, i would ping the sdk team over in <#C1GSVKK1U|nodesdk>
although - when I run membersrvc I would expect it to log something to the console
which it doesn't
my guess is: its nothing to do with you, just a bug in the particular tree you checked out
yeah, more recent versions of membersrvc are disturbingly silent
but this is in fact normal
i was tripped up by this myself a few weeks ago
mmhh - ok
thought it was busted, spent 10 minutes chasing it down
i think you can modify the logging levels if you want the old behavior
make behave also gives...
but I havent tried this, i just accepted that it was FAD and moved on

``` When requesting "/chain" from "vp0"                                                                               # None
    Then I should get a JSON response with "height" = "3"                                                             # None

14:36:11 - context.failed = True

Failing scenarios:
  java_shim.feature:121  Java TableExample chaincode single peer

4 features passed, 1 failed, 3 skipped
39 scenarios passed, 1 failed, 9 skipped
549 steps passed, 1 failed, 270 skipped, 0 undefined
Took 18m53.530s
make: *** [behave] Error 1
```
unless you changed the code, i wouldn’t worry about behave failing _too_ much…there were some flaky tests in behave so it was removed from the CI verification process until it can be fixed
this means two things
1) theres been a long history of flaky tests, this could be one of them
2) because its no longer verified by CI, its highly likely that new failing tests have been introduced
ok which means the docs are behind
yes
its good to be aware of in general, as we need to get it fixed again
but jfyi, its currently flaky and thus you can expect some failures if you run it
its not necessarily an indication that your environment is messed up
sure - being a noob to the HL environment there's a lot of moving parts and yes I understand it's incubation but it's confusing when exposed to it...
so all I was trying to do was follow (the disjointed) docs to get one example working...
sure, and sorry
no need to apologize bud
well, i understand, and I feel bad
we are working on it, though
it's not like the Fabric is at a LTS stage and something's wonky
right, though getting things as smooth as possible is important
If I may say, I think the core problem here is the existence of only a "developer VM image" and not also of a "instant fabric in a can" VM image
that point is not lost
we are actively working on this
at least from a docker workflow
it should soon be possible to just do something like “docker run hyperledger/fabric-peer"
kind of like how kubernetes works
cool
but its not quite ironed out yet
perhaps - I've been working with Mike @ Cloudsoft ito getting a localised VM setup working that would be truly representative of a production environment with multiple nodes etc
<@U2CC1NDT2> and def keep us all in the loop on your progress there
ok followed -> <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/nodeSDK/sample-standalone-app/> exactly and it doesn't work it seems
just sits at...
```enrolling user admin ...```
the couldsoft AMP setup works well - we've ironed out port issues and docker restart issues and and and - but I need to spend some time doing a complete from the ground up test install, tear down etc
i reviewed the overall steps there, they look reasonably correct so Im guessing the problem is in the sdk/app.js side
must me - I'm no expert but I "think" it could be related to the following code...
my only comment there is, I never work with the sdk src…i have applications that pull official hfc releases from npm
sorry - need to feed my dog...
so i wonder if you are getting bit by some transient problem in the unreleased SDK
sure, ill be here

cause when it runs...
```vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-131b36c:/tmp$ node app
 **** starting HFC sample ****
member services address =undefined
peer address =undefined
DEPLOY_MODE=undefined
enrolling user admin ...
```
surely the addresses need to resolve
its possible it assumes “localhost” but im guessing that is your (or really “the docs”) problem
mmhh - can't say other than it never completes
try this
so I can with conviction say that these docs don't work atm -> <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/nodeSDK/sample-standalone-app/>
add "CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 MEMBERSRVC_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7054 DEPLOY_MODE=dev node app"
(I am not sure what schema the DEPLOY_MODE needs
i just winged that
but you are using devmode if you followed the instructions on that link you sent
so im guessing its something like “dev” “devmode” etc
yeah - i decided to start completely from scratch - so following the threads in the doc....
BINGO!
by visual inspection, i think the steps up to the nodejs parts look correct
working?

```vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-131b36c:/tmp$ CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 MEMBERSRVC_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7054 DEPLOY_MODE=dev node app
 **** starting HFC sample ****
member services address =0.0.0.0:7054
peer address =0.0.0.0:7051
DEPLOY_MODE=dev
enrolling user admin ...
Enrolled JohnDoe successfully

deploying chaincode; please wait ...
Failed to deploy chaincode: request={"fcn":"init","args":["a","100","b","200"],"chaincodePath":"<http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02>"}, error=%k { error: [Error: missing chaincodeName in DeployRequest],
  msg: 'Error: missing chaincodeName in DeployRequest' }
```
nice!
thats progress at least
yup!
although it seems the app.js code is broken....

```{ error: [Error: missing chaincodeName in DeployRequest],
  msg: 'Error: missing chaincodeName in DeployRequest' }```
yes, there was a change not that long ago regarding chaincodeName, im guessing the sample wasnt updated
its an easy fix if you want to hack locally though
hold on
incubation is fluid... :slightly_smiling_face:
happy to
ok, you dont need to change code
its another envcar
envvar
set CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc
in addition to the others
you might run into an issue where the JohnDoe user is now already created
if you see an error about logging in, let me know, I can tell you how to reset the environment
but I _think_ if you set those 4 envvars, it will work
yeah baby!

```vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-131b36c:/tmp$ CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 MEMBERSRVC_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7054 DEPLOY_MODE=dev node app

query completed successfully; results={"result":{"type":"Buffer","data":[57,57]}}
vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-131b36c:/tmp$

nice!
could you do me a favor and file a JIRA entry against that doc?
ok so need to note that for the doc folks
sure
(if you want to submit a patch for it too, greatly appreciated
but whatever you feel comfortable with
would love to - don't know how but willing to learn...
are you comfortable with git in general and just need to learn gerrit?
or is git submission new too?
have to get my kid ready for school, bbiab
<@U0KPFAZNF> I’d love to listen in too :slightly_smiling_face:
later bud - thanks for the help....
I’d love to increase the bag of tricks
it's ALL new....
but willing to learn and put in the time....
```Congratulations! You’ve successfully run your first Hyperledger fabric application.```
is actually a little meaningless...
whilst being absolutely brilliant :slightly_smiling_face: if you follow me...
but progress - no doubt...
back
so, to start, you will need a linux foundation login to access both jira and gerrit, if you dont already have one
got that\
ok, cool
so, creating the jira is trivial then, i think
cant pull the repo without same
oh, well it depends on how you cloned it
(for instane, you can clone the GH mirror without credentials)
shouldn't be - I had my team using jira years ago
but it sounds like you cloned from gerrit using the ssh url, which is good
should be able to figure it out...
it will make it easier
yup with my LFID
ok, cool
since im not sure of your familiarity with git concepts, ill start basic but just tell me if you want to fast forward
in a nutshell, one of the most confusing things for people new to git is the notion that each “clone” is essentially a full copy of the repo, history and all
therefore, there are two classes of commands
ones that operate just on your local clone, and ones that are meant to synchronize between clones
“git commit” falls into the former category, but this often catches people by surprise since “commit” sounds all official
it just means its commited to your local copy
and you dont need permissions (or even an active internet connection) to do this
i've used git locally only for my own needs - never pushing to a "master"
ok, cool
so, the next level then is the pushing/pulling
now, for normal git, you typically can push patches right to some remote repo, assuming you have write permissions
you can do this various ways, but one way might look something like “git push origin HEAD:my-new-branch"
i've found git to be a rather confusing "young lady"....
ok...
that says push my current tree (“HEAD” to a remote branch called “my-new-branch"
(on the repo “origin"
sure - but issued from what dir?
and in this case... we set cmd line args?
but we have this thing in the middle (gerrit) which acts as a gate for submissions..you cant write to the tree directly
generally, from anywhere in the tree where your repo is
though i tend to do most operations from the root of the project
some commands, like git ls-files can be context specific
that said, I think “git push” isnt
so help me here - i cloned the repo - it's on  my local and mapped to my VM
but I just make a habit of being in the root
so now I wanna make a change to the doc...
yep, and technically you could do these operations from either your host or the VM
how?
but I would advise you do them from the host
ok...
it will have your editor, etc
ok i get it... pull the doc from gerrit
branch it
push it?
so, as you probably know from the past experience, edit the doc locally
yep, the branching is up to you
when you commit don't forget to add `Signed-off-by: your name <email address>`
but you would generally be doing pull -> edit -> commit -> push
ok so one thing - how do i pull just that doc?
yes, good point <@U0ZJZBJLF> , there are several requirements for the commit message you attache
sorry guys real noob to this
<@U2CC1NDT2> there might be ways to pull just the file, but that is not what I would do
yes - saw that - will read the guidelines
you don't pull just the doc, you just change the doc and then git knows what're the changes and paints them red/green
just work with the entire tree
ok but guys where on my local is the doc? that's my question
right, as <@U0ZJZBJLF> mentioned, git will know you only changed N files
oh, i see
i think its in one of the .md files, but we’d have to search for it
ok /docs
I think there is a wiki repo which is different from the fabric
if he needs to change there
i think in this case its an .md change
in the fabric.git
ok slowwwwwly getting it
in /hyperldeger/docs
yeah, its likely in there
make the change then "git push origin HEAD:my-new-branch"
so you just edit the .md file to taste, and when its ready git-commit and then git-push it to gerrit
well, almost
gerrit is a little weird
to gerrit?
you dont have direct write access to the tree, you need to make a proposal
ok
to do that, you basically do “git push origin HEAD:refs/for/$branch"
or... you can just install git-review and it'll do the dirty work for you
where $branch is the upstream branch you are proposing to modify, like “master” or “v0.6"
and then you can just "git-review" and that's it
ill defer to <@U0ZJZBJLF> on git-review, i dont use it so I cant offer any advice there
but I know plenty of folks do
ok better - so git push origin HEAD:refs/for/git-review?

you can read here, if you want. 
<https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Gerrit/git-review>
no, i think it would be something like "git push origin HEAD:refs/for/master”, or you can alternatively use git-review instead of manually managing the push
it also does a rebase for you, by the way
ok - no probs - will dive into this and see what's what...
now, once you do that, if everything is formatted correctly, your proposal will show up in the UI here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/status:open>
there are a couple of things though to note
your commit message has several requirements
<@U0KPFAZNF> , do you do non-environmental CRs?
<@U0ZJZBJLF> already mentioned the SIgned-off-by
You will also need a ChangeId, which you can read about here <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/Documentation/user-upload.html#push_create>
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/Documentation/user-changeid.html>
there is a local git hook you can install which is detailed in those instructions which will generate this for you
and lastly, i think we limit line length to something like 70 characters
but assuming all of that looks good, it will show up in the UI for others to review
ok - will go on this side mission to figure out how to use git / gerrit properly - never envisaged getting involved at this level but all good...
its totally up to you, but we appreciate the contribution if you decide to
guess that's what makes community :slightly_smiling_face:
its a slight PITA to deal with gerrit, but once you get it its not that hard to use
<@U0ZJZBJLF> I am not even sure what “non-environmental CRs” are, so I am guessing the answer is “no” :wink:
fabric stuff, that aren't related to fabric-dev-env
like ledger code, peer code, etc. etc.
oh, of course, heh
someone needs to sweep the floors and clean the toilets, though :wink:
not urgent, was just asking for general knowledge
but yeah, i was involved in some of the core code early on…lately ive been more distracted with implementing my use case on top of HL than HL core itself
but I hope to get back into fabric dev more over the next few months
I do feel we need a "dumb-ass 1st look newbie guide"
<@U0ZJZBJLF> I wrote the chaintool infrastructure for one thing, though
something that can guide people coming from the outside to ease their way into HL
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool>
<@U2CC1NDT2> yeah, point taken…i know we are trying to get our wiki setup which will help with that
also, the guides as you mention
there are so many moving parts (apart from the fact HL is in incubation) that it makes it frustrating to navigate the landscape
cool
of course when V1.0 happens and we get to LTS things will settle down.,...

<@U2CC1NDT2> yeah, and I think you are entering at a particularly tumultuous time…things are being refactored etc…a lot of the doc was w.r.t. the v0.5 design and a lot of it is changing in the features/convergence branch
so people that are coming in are getting caught in the middle of the two
and unless you are "inside" it leaves one in a vacuum...
yeah, and even when you are “inside” its not always easy to follow the rapidly evolving code base
along with the "strange" design decisions like dumping the REST API
heh, well, that makes more sense when you know the history
it was the presence of the API itself that was perhaps “strange"
:wink:
i can explain that statement, though
but suffice to say, it was a non-inuitive architectural detail that caused great confusion
so, it going away is part of the effort to straighten that out
I just find it odd that we have the 3 layers - core -chaincode and whatever else and the whatever else layer which should be "open" is being pushed to Node
unless i'm missing something (which is quite likely through lack of knowledge..)
the basic issue is that the “peer” codebase was designed to be used in two distinct different contexts…and the API was exposing one of those contexts
but because it was attached to one “process”, the lines became blurred
if you think that's odd you're in for a treat for future releases...
ok.... but i would think we would want to make it "easy" from the outer ring inwards...
so web apps - build in whatever - here's the API
chaincode - go / java
core - it's specifics
thats exactly the intention
before, part of the “webapp” stack was integrated into the peer when running in NVP mode
the REST interface served to connect the front end and backend in this capacity
but in doing so, it required a very unatural relationship to security details
I also get that codebases are being merged and that in itself is no mean feat
so, those aspects are being broken out so that the portions that were handled by “client NVP” are integrated into the SDK that runs coresident with the app
which is much more natural from a security perspective…and also, should help to reduce process sprawl
sure - cbf suggested possibly something like -> <https://github.com/grpc-ecosystem/grpc-gateway>

attachments.title: grpc-ecosystem/grpc-gateway
attachments.text: grpc-gateway - gRPC to JSON proxy generator

text: as an abstraction
this isnt to indict REST apis vs something else…but rather, the REST API that was implemented served the front-end/back-end interface for this client NVP thing
and since the client NVP thing is going away, the REST API is too
if that makes sense
I guess what I'm getting it is REST is "easy" for web-app dev's to wrap their heads wound...
which would go a long way to getting community adoption
yeah, understood…the problem is the crypto, etc, are not trivial
yes 100%
so, it was felt it could be expressed more precisely with GRPC schema than, say, swagger, and then that can be the integration point
(its probably more important to “pick one” than “pick X"
but GRPC was the decision
anyway, the intetion is that your typically webapp would interface to say a nodejs backend, and that would inteface to the SDK which manages the GRPC for you
I am sure the decision re gRPC was correct but the idea of a gRPC/JSON proxy on the face of it sounds like a viable solution
but hey what the hell do I know
yes, i agree..I think that is the intention
you would have to replicate the crypto protocols, etc, but it should be possible
but this is exactly what we are seeing now…we have proposals for SDKs in node, python, java
coded to the GRPC “standard"
but coudn't the node sdk be proxied?
yes, it was designed for this
for instance, the notion of “registrar” is precisely to deal with proxy scenarios
i tried to find the .proto files in the node sdk (HFC node install)...
look in fabric.git…they are mostly under ./protos and copied to the SDK during compilation
not sure where they end up in the NPM package
ok, kid to bus now…bbiab
yeah I saw those but for the life of me it made no sense - but also I'm no kick-ass developer
later bud

so, since you're here <@U0KPFAZNF> - you know of the go-logging issue that fails our tests from time to time?
oh I didn't see that kid-->bus line
back
<@U0ZJZBJLF> i’ve seen it in passing but I do not know the details there
so TLDR- go-logging isn't thread safe when SetLevel is called concurrently with any logging method
I created a test that fails 100% of the time, and I created a patch that fixes it and the test doesn't fail
and uploaded to gerrit
oh, right, and you were asking if its ok to patch the vendor code?
I think it's ok according to what the license says
<https://github.com/op/go-logging/blob/master/LICENSE>
I opened an issue to them but they didn't respond :disappointed: so I decided to patch it myself cause it's annoying
i guess we havent had this come up so I dont have a strong opinion one way or the other
It usually makes crypto tests fail
one part of me says: we maintain the code in our tree for this reason
the other part says: this makes it ripe for a maintenance burden going forward
i think I would say: its fine to carry the patch as long as we also make a reasonable attempt to upstream the patch in accordance with the project in question
it sounds like you already did this
<https://github.com/op/go-logging/issues/104>

attachments.title: Thread safety · Issue #104 · op/go-logging · GitHub
attachments.text: Hi. Logger.log() calls moduleLeveled.Log() which calls moduleLeveled.GetLevel(), which does a map read. Now, var defaultBackend LeveledBackend is a global field. If someone calls concurrently logg...

text: good…next best thing: submit a PR?
to them? sure I can...
I think if you do the issue/PR, and patch locally, thats the best we can do
but if they didn't respond to my issue in 2 days I think nothing promises that they merge the PR
thing is- I can't patch locally, i need someone to... CR it :wink:
the only question in my mind is: how do we prevent an accidental overwrite in a future vendor update
of course, thats what I meant sorry
i meant “locally == hyperledger project locally"
I'll publish a PR and if they merge I guess I'll get an email
heres something to consider
we could consider forking the project, presumably under the hyperledger governance, and having fabric import that
that would make it more difficult to have a vendor update stomp on your work
but is it worth it?  i am not sure
dunno, I'm not that of a far-thinker, I just want my CI jobs to pass with a higher probability
selfish, I know
perhaps best course of action is: consider merging local CR in the short term….wait and see how their community responds to the PR
ok
if they accept the PR in a reasonable timeframe, we bump vendor rev and be done
if they dont, we consider forking
ok I'll send a PR today
ty
but of course you can take a look at the local PR
to be clear, i have no problem with your tactical solution…i understand and appreciate the urgency
and in fact, would argue thats one of the reasons to have the code local like that
I mean, if you have time of course
sure, ill take a look after lunch
my primary concern is long term, we forget the context and lose your fix in a future vendor rev…as long as that doesnt happen, I am happy

outsider opinion - vendor issues / motivation shouldn't be part of the thinking - this is supposed to be a community project now (and yes I understand they've devoted value) but you can't pick and choose
IMHO
H-humble not honest
but hey ho I'm just some douche living in Mauritius with a PC and an Internet connection... :slightly_smiling_face:
bon weekend folks
<@U0KPFAZNF> - thanks for the assist today - one step closer...
<@U2CC1NDT2> yw…im also not clear on what you were saying above about vendor issues

im looking at it purely from a code maintenance perspective…patching the vendor folder in certain ways carries a cost, that is all..i would ideally like to minimize the cost and also keep the probability of a mistake in the future to a minimum
i was speaking out of turn I feel... apologies to all...

<@U0ZJZBJLF> you may already have done this: but can you ensure we have UT coverage executed along with the rest of fabric UTs for the problem you are highlighting so that we ensure the fix is not reverted in the future?
how do I do that?
and I don't really understand what you mean
jenkins executes them doesn't it?
id have to look at the specifics, but say you added something like fabric.git/tests/gologging_test.go
you want me to move it to another place ?
and have it reproduce the problem you are seeing
I have a test I wrote but I placed it inside the vendor folder
im not saying anything specific like that, other than can you figure out a way to regression test your fix?
yeah, we dont include vendor stuff in the tests currently
so, one way or another, if it can be included, that would make me feel better
i just want to catch something like, say 18 months from now, someone vendor revs go-logging and overwrites your patch
wait actually something isn't clear to me now- how do the vendor folders get updated in fabric?
ive actually never done it, but my understanding is the “govendor” tool is used
since they're in the git tree
oh... I see.
and that tool will update the ./vendor folder for you
I can move the test to a different folder, but which one you'd suggest to?
i think this scenario doesnt have precedent, so we need to decide what makes sense
maybe ./tests/third-party/gologging_test.go ?
i am open
there is no tests
understood
why not to core/util/util_tests.go ?
it's just a small simple test
sure, that works for me
k i'm on it
ty
to be clear: you should probably leave the UT with the vendor patch too, if that makes sense
er, what gets pushed upstream should have a test…but also, we need a way to ensure we dont regress
my thought is: this might be best implemented as a DRY violation (test in both vendor and fabric)
but I am open
another alternative might be to special case the go-logging folder in the test exclusions
as long as you find a way to tie the regression test into the fabric UTs, I am happy
done
why in both?
i don't understand
well, I think the patch that you submit to upstream PR should include test
i think fabric.git needs regression proof
and I suspect the easiest way to get there is to basically have your PR in the vendor folder and perhaps a fabric specific test
but ultimately, there are many ways to solve that problem
that's what i did- the bug fix is in the vendor folder, the regression test is in core/util/util_test
for instance, you could patch fabric/vendor without the test in vendor, if you dont mind maintaining the difference between fabric.git/vendor and go-logging.git
my inclination would be to keep fabric.git/vendor as close to what I pushed upstream, but that is just me
it's only a 5 line change in vendor
that's it
ok, thats fine…i leave it up to you
ok. could you take a look at this some time when you're not busy?
hah, don’t qualify it with the last 4 words or its not going to happen :wink:
what was the link again?
ty
